Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: A cruising aircraft simply requests the routine altimeter setting.
Story:
I had just moved into my new apartment, and the box of homemade cake sat on my kitchen counter, ready for a neighborly introduction. I wanted to make a good impression, to be the kind of friendly, approachable neighbor people remembered. As I stepped into the hallway, I spotted Mrs. Kim from next door fumbling with her groceries. I smiled, cake in hand, and started toward her, rehearsing my greeting in my head.

But just then, my headset crackled. I was on call, working remotely as an air traffic controller. A pilot’s voice came through, requesting the routine altimeter setting. My job demanded immediate, precise communication—lives depended on it. I froze, torn between the expectation to be a warm, welcoming neighbor and the urgent responsibility to respond to the pilot. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, cake in one hand, headset in the other, caught between two worlds and unable to move.
